posts.title: ¡Cuba Sí!
posts.excerpt: Documentarists tend to be an eccentric breed. They need to be, since none of the main film festivals allow their films into competition (an incomprehensible decision), and to get a documentary into a cinema these days is a fraught process. But there is no more highly personal yet elusive film-maker than Chris Marker. His importance …

posts._title: Zelimir Zilnik – Tito po drugi put medju srbima AKA Tito Among the Serbs for the Second Time (1993)
posts.title: Tito po drugi put medju srbima
posts.excerpt: Synopsis:A man dressed in Marshal Tito’s uniform appears and, instantly, groups of people flock around him. In this film, Žilnik brings the former Yugoslav leader back to the streets of Belgrade to see how his people are now living without him. Tito’s double wanders around the city and procures remarkable reactions as people come up …
posts.titleEnglish: Tito Among the Serbs for the Second Time

posts.title: Wonderful Copenhagen
posts.excerpt: Like a bulletin board that has all kinds of notices next to each other, Jenoe Farkas’ documentary on the various inhabitants of Copenhagen, filmed over a several-year period, has all sorts of people and events on display, but not one unifying theme or any cinematic artifice to link them together.

posts._title: Roman Polanski – Death and the Maiden (1994)
posts.title: Death and the Maiden
posts.excerpt: Quote:In a remote beach house on a cliff, a woman (Sigourney Weaver) rewards the doctor (Ben Kingsley) who gave her lawyer husband (Stuart Wilson) a lift home on a stormy night by tying him to a chair, stuffing his mouth with her panties and holding a gun to his head. A twisted romantic triangle? You …

posts._title: Måns Månsson & Hongqi Li – Stranded in Canton (2014)
posts.title: Stranded in Canton
posts.excerpt: Congolese democracy entrepreneur Lebrun takes us on a tangled, tender and cruel adventure to finalise a Chinese T-shirt deal which is turning sour. Between documentary and fiction, this tragicomedy sketches the outlines of a world without the West.

posts._title: Jean Epstein – Six et demi onze (1927)
posts.title: Six et demi onze
posts.excerpt: Quote:Female infidelity leads a man, Jean, to commit suicide. When he is dead his brother, Jerôme, starts having an affair with the same woman, Mary. But… there is a photography left of her first brother, who the second is getting closer to finding – hence the title (6,5 X 11 – an film negative format). …

posts._title: Raoul Ruiz – La colonia penal aka The Penal Colony (1970)
posts.title: La colonia penal
posts.excerpt: Quote:A foreign journalist arrives on a small Pacific island 200 miles off the coast of South America. Once a leper colony, the island was later transformed into a prison and then, under U.N. mandate, made into an independent republic. Yet despite democratic structures, the inhabitants–who speak a strange dialect composed of Spanish and English–still obey …

posts._title: Ebbo Demant – Auf der Suche nach der verlorenen Zeit. Andrej Tarkowskijs Exil und Tod aka The Exile and Death of Andrei Tarkovsky (1988)
posts.title: Auf der Suche nach der verlorenen Zeit Andrej Tarkowskijs Exil und Tod
posts.excerpt: Description:Documentary on the final years in the life of director Andrej Tarkovsky, who died in 1986, including his exile in Western Europe. The film shows the degree to which the themes of his films, NOSTALGHIA and the SACRIFICE almost literally came to encapsulate the director’s own life and death.
posts.titleEnglish: The Exile and Death of Andrei Tarkovsky

posts.title: What Goes Up
posts.excerpt: A volley of rapid visual associations from the mind of Robert Breer, animating collage, drawings and snapshots in a playful, but rigorous manner. What goes up must come down.

posts._title: Virgilio Tosi – The Origins of Scientific Cinematography (1990)
posts.title: The Origins of Scientific Cinematography
posts.excerpt: Quote:THE ORIGINS OF SCIENTIFIC CINEMATOGRAPHY is a documentary film series directed by Virgilio Tosi. The films complement Tosi’s book Cinema Before Cinema, using archive film and original equipment to show how cinematography had its origins not in the music hall or the fairground, but in the laboratory, as scientists of the 19th and early 20th …
